case_name: Balraj Khanna & Ors. v. Moti Ram

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 14 of 1971 was filed by special leave against Delhi High Court judgment dated August 26, 1970

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 14 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated, August 26, 1970 of the Delhi High Court in Criminal Revision, No. 138 of 1968.

facts.text: Delhi High Court judgment in Criminal Revision No. 138 of 1968 dated August 26, 1970

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated, August 26, 1970 of the Delhi High Court in Criminal Revision, No. 138 of 1968.

facts.text: Respondent Moti Ram filed complaint against seven appellants under Section 500 IPC in court of Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Delhi

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Moti Ram filed a companyplaint in the companyrt of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Delhi against the seven appellants under section 500 I. P. C. alleging that they made certain allegations against him which were defamatory in character

facts.text: Respondent was serving as Liaison Officer, Municipal Corporation, Delhi during December 1964

anchor.surface_text: The respondent during December, 1964 was serving as a Liaison Officer, Municipal Corporation, Delhi.

facts.text: Appellants were members of the Standing Committee of the Municipal Corporation in December 1964

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were among the members of the Standing Committee of the Corporation at that time.

facts.text: Standing Committee meeting held on December 10, 1964 to move resolution for immediate suspension of respondent

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly a meeting of the Standing Committee was held on December 10, 1964. The said meeting was attended, number only by the Commissioner and other officers of the Corporation, but also by the press reporters.

facts.text: Appellants made defamatory allegations against respondent in Standing Committee meeting on December 10, 1964

anchor.surface_text: In that meeting the appel- lants made very serious allegations of a defamatory nature against the respondent and passed unanimously a resolution placing him under immediate suspension.

facts.text: Standing Committee passed resolution on December 10, 1964 placing respondent under immediate suspension

anchor.surface_text: passed unanimously a resolution placing him under immediate suspension.

facts.text: Meeting attended by Commissioner, officers, and press reporters

anchor.surface_text: The said meeting was attended, number only by the Commissioner and other officers of the Corporation, but also by the press reporters.

facts.text: Allegations against respondent and suspension given wide publicity harming his reputation

anchor.surface_text: The allegations made against the respondent and the fact of his suspension from office were given wide publicity, with the result that it brought down the respondent in the estimation of his friends causing harm to his reputation.

facts.text: P.W. 3, Secretary of Corporation, sent report Ex. P.W. 3/B on December 11, 1964 regarding allegations

anchor.surface_text: P. W. 3, who was the Secretary of the Corporation, and who attended the meeting of the Standing Committee on December 10, 1964 sent a report the next day Ex. P. W. 3 B to the Commissioner regarding the allegations

facts.text: Seven appellants conspired in October 1964 to defame respondent and remove him from service

anchor.surface_text: In the companyplaint it is further stated that in October, 1964, all the seven appellants entered into a companyspiracy to defame the respondent and remove him from the municipal service

facts.text: Magistrate examined respondent and five other witnesses under Section 202 Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Magistrate the respondent and five other Witnesses were examine under section 202,Cr.P.C.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate dismissed complaint under Section 203 Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: and after companysideration of the evidence the Magistrate dismissed the companyplaint under section 203.Cr.P.C.

facts.text: Magistrate's dismissal grounds: no evidence which appellant made which allegation; protected by exceptions to Section 499 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The dismissal of the companyplaint by the Magistrate is rested on two ground,namely, 1 there is numberevidence on record as to which of the appellants made which allegation against the respondent... 2 the resolution passed by the Standing Committee and the discussion preceding it are companyered by the Exceptions to Section 499 1. C.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi dismissed respondent's revision summarily

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi, dismissed the revision of the respondent summarily

facts.text: Delhi High Court set aside Magistrate's dismissal order and directed further inquiry by Chief Judicial Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the High Court set aside the order of the Magistrate dismissing the companyplaint under Section 203 Cr. C. and directed further inquiry to be made into the companyplaint by the Chief Judicial Magistrate, Delhi

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Allegations in Ex. P.W. 3/B include respondent deficient in duties as Liaison Officer

anchor.surface_text: The allegations referred to in P. W. 3 1 B are as follows Since its inception in 1958 the Corporation has executed a very heavy programme of works... The L.O. has, thus number performed the duties which are required of the post he has been holding and has been deficient in the performance of his duties.

facts.text: Allegations include respondent indulging in acts of moral turpitude and seducing girls and women

anchor.surface_text: He is known for indulging in acts of moral turpitude and for seducing unsuspecting girls and women.

facts.text: First appellant Balraj Khanna was inimical towards respondent

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant Balraj Khanna was bitterly inimical towards the respondent and was bent upon causing harm to him.

facts.text: Three other members besides seven appellants passed the suspension resolution

anchor.surface_text: apart from the seven appellants, three other members of the Standing Committee were also parties to this resolution

facts.text: Appellants gave publicity to resolution in local newspapers

anchor.surface_text: After passing the resolution the appellants with the ulterior motive of maligning the respondent and lowering him in the estimation of the public gave publicity to the resolution in the local newspapers with large circulation.

facts.text: Supreme Court held prima facie case made out against appellants based on complaint allegations

anchor.surface_text: From the averments made in the companyplaint... we are of the opinion, that the companyplainant has. furnished in a substantial measure the words of imputation, which, according to him, are defamatory.

facts.text: Court found Magistrate's approach erroneous regarding lack of specific attribution of allegations

anchor.surface_text: This, in our opinion, is a fallacious approach made by the Magistrate in the face of the allegation made by the respondent that all the seven appellants made the statements referred to in Ex. P. W. 3/B.

under section 500 I. P. C.

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle for sufficiency of defamation complaint allegations

issues.text: The question arises whether in an action for defamation under Section 500 I. P. C., it is necessary that the actual statements containing the words alleged to have been used by the accused must be before the court or whether it is enough that the statements alleged to have been made are substantially reproduced in the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The question arises whether in an action for defamation under Section 500 I. P. C., it is necessary that the actual statements containing the words alleged to have been used by the accused must be before the court or whether it is enough that the statements alleged to have been made are substantially reproduced in the complaint.

issues.text: The further question is whether the complaint in this case is defective in the sense that the actual statements alleged to have been made by the individual accused have not been stated in the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The further question is whether the complaint in this case is defective in the sense that the actual statements alleged to have been made by the individual accused have not been stated in the complaint.

issues.text: Whether there is a prima facie case made out against the appellants on the materials in the complaint under Sections 202 and 203 Cr. P. C.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Magistrate the respondent and five other Witnesses were examined under section 202,Cr.P.C. and after consideration of the evidence the Magistrate dismissed the complaint under section 203.Cr.P.C.The dismissal of the complaint by the Magistrate is rested on two grounds,namely, 1 there is noevidence on record as to which of the appellants made which allegation against the respondent and in the absence of such an important ingredient, noprima facie case against any of the appellants can be said to have been made out,

issues.text: Whether the resolution passed by the Standing Committee and the discussion preceding it are covered by the Exceptions to Section 499 I. P. C.

anchor.surface_text: the Magistrate dismissed the complaint under section 203.Cr.P.C.The dismissal of the complaint by the Magistrate is rested on two grounds,namely, 1 there is noevidence on record as to which of the appellants made which allegation against the respondent and in the absence of such an important ingredient, noprima facie case against any of the appellants can be said to have been made out, and  2  the resolution passed by the Standing Committee and the discussion preceding it are considered by the Exceptions to Section 499 1. C.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was correct in setting aside the Magistrate's order dismissing the complaint under Section 203 Cr. P. C. and directing further inquiry.

arguments.claim: In defamation under S.500 IPC, substantial reproduction of statements in complaint sufficient; not necessary actual words verbatim, especially for spoken words

anchor.surface_text: The question arises whether... it is enough that the statements alleged to have been made are substantially reproduced in the complaint.

arguments.claim: English libel precedents requiring verbatim words not applicable to spoken defamation under IPC S.499

anchor.surface_text: the propositions laid down in English decisions dealing with libel that the actual words alleged to be used must be stated in the indictment cannot be applied on all fours when dealing with the cases of defamation by spoken words

arguments.claim: Complaint not defective for lack of individual statements by each accused since alleges all seven made the (same) allegations in Ex. P.W. 3/B
Exceptions to S.499 IPC not to be considered at S.203 CrPC dismissal stage; for trial

holdings.text: In a prosecution for defamation by spoken words under Section 500 IPC, it is sufficient if the complainant substantially reproduces the words of imputation in the complaint; verbatim reproduction of actual words is not necessary, especially for lengthy statements.

anchor.surface_text: After a companysideration of the various decisions referred to above, we are of the opinion that the propositions laid down in English decisions dealing with libel that the actual words alleged to be used must be stated in the indictment cannot be applied on all fours when dealing with the cases of defamation by spoken words under Section 499 I. P. C. it will be highly desirable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes English libel precedents requiring verbatim words (written) from spoken defamation under IPC; purposive interpretation allows substance for practicality as exact recall impossible; serves purpose of assessing defamatory nature.

holdings.text: The complaint is not defective for failing to attribute specific statements to individual accused where it alleges that all seven appellants collectively made the same defamatory statements referred to in Ex. P.W. 3/B.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of complaint allegations; no need for individualisation when joint attribution claimed; evidentiary proof deferred to trial.

holdings.text: A prima facie case is made out against the appellants based on the complaint materials under Sections 202 and 203 Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: From the averments made in the companyplaint, which refers to various matters referred to in Ex. P.W., 3 B, we are of the opinion, that the companyplainant has. furnished in a substantial measure the words of imputation, which, according to him, are defamatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Complaint furnishes substantial imputation words; applies Chandra Deo Singh standard - Magistrate ascertains prima facie from complaint, not conviction sufficiency.

holdings.text: The applicability of Exceptions to Section 499 IPC does not arise at the Section 203 Cr.P.C. dismissal stage and must be considered during trial.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural stage limits inquiry to prima facie case; defences like exceptions deferred to trial where full evidence adduced.

holdings.text: The Delhi High Court correctly set aside the Magistrate's dismissal order under Section 203 Cr.P.C. and directed further inquiry; the Magistrate's approach was erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: This, in our opinion, is a fallacious approach made by the Magistrate in the face of the allegation made by the respondent that all the seven appellants made the statements referred to in Ex. P. W. 3/B. In our opinion, the High Court has made a correct approach

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees entirely with High Court reasoning rejecting Magistrate's lack of attribution and exceptions grounds; prima facie case exists collectively.

holdings.text: Under Sections 202 and 203 Cr.P.C., the Magistrate must determine if a prima facie case exists from complaint materials, not assess evidence sufficiency for conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Before we refer to the decisions... it is necessary to clear the ground by appreciating the nature of the jurisdiction exercised by the Magistrate under Sections 202 and 203 Cr. P. C. In Chandra Deo Singh v. Prokash Chandra Bose and another, it has been held by this Court that the object of the provisions of Section 202 Cr. P. C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in Chandra Deo Singh; preliminary inquiry limited to prima facie support in complaint.

precedents.citation: Chandra Deo Singh v. Prokash Chandra Bose and another

anchor.surface_text: In Chandra Deo Singh v. Prokash Chandra Bose and another  1 , it has been held by this Court that the object of the provisions of Section 202 Cr. P. C. is to enable the, Magistrate to form an opnion as to whether process should be issued or number.

precedents.case_name: Chandra Deo Singh v. Prokash Chandra Bose and another
precedents.cited_proposition: object of the provisions of Section 202 Cr. P. C. is to enable the Magistrate to form an opinion as to whether process should be issued or not. At that stage what the Magistrate has to see is whether there is evidence in support of the allegations made in the complaint and not whether the evidence is sufficient to warrant a conviction
precedents.cited_holding: function of the Magistrate holding the preliminary inquiry is only to be satisfied that a prima facie case is made out against the accused on the materials placed before him by the complainant

precedents.citation: Charles Bhedlaugh and Annie Besant v. The Queer  1  3 Q.B.D. 607

anchor.surface_text: In Charles Bhedlaugh and Annie Besant v. The Queer  1  the Court of Appeal was dealing with an indictment for publishing an obscene book. Bramwell, I,. J., observes as follows In some instances, words are the subject- matter of an indictment

precedents.case_name: Charles Bhedlaugh and Annie Besant v. The Queen
precedents.cited_proposition: wherever the offence consists of words written or spoken, those words must be stated in the indictment if they are not, it will be defective

precedents.citation: The Capital and Counties Bank Limited v. George Henty and sons  1  7 Appeal Cases 741

anchor.surface_text: In The Capital and Counties Bank Limited v. George Henty and sons  1  Lord Blackburn in dealing with an action for libel states as follows The words themselves must have been set out in the declaration or indictment

precedents.case_name: Capital and Counties Bank Limited v. George Henty and sons
precedents.cited_proposition: The words themselves must have been set out in the declaration or indictment, in order that the Court might be able to judge whether they were a libel or not

precedents.citation: Collins v. Jones  2  1955.2 All England Reports 145

anchor.surface_text: In Collins v. Jones  2 , Lord Denning quoted with approval the observations of Lord Coleridge. C. J. in Harris v. Waree as follows In libel and slander everything may turn on the form of words

precedents.cited_proposition: quoted with approval the observations of Lord Coleridge C.J. in Harris v. Ware

anchor.surface_text: Lord Denning quoted with approval the observations of Lord Coleridge. C. J. in Harris v. Waree as follows In libel and slander everything may turn on the form of words, and in olden days plaintiffs constantly failed from small and even unimportant variance

precedents.cited_proposition: In libel and slander everything may turn on the form of words
precedents.cited_holding: the very words complained of are the facts on which the action is grounded

precedents.citation: Sarat Chandra Das and another v. The State 1  and Krishnarao v. Firm Radhakisan Ramshai and another

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Daphtary also referred us to the decisions in Sarat Chandra Das and another v. The State 1  and Krishnarao v. Firm Radhakisan Ramshai and another In the Orissa High Court decision two accused were being tried for an offence under Section 500 I.P.C.

precedents.case_name: Sarat Chandra Das and another v. The State
precedents.cited_proposition: in a trial for defamation it is essential that the words alleged to be defamatory in character should be precisely set out and the accused should be individually given notice of what he is charged with

precedents.citation: Krishnarao v. Firm Radhakisan Ramshai and another

anchor.surface_text: Sarat Chandra Das and another v. The State 1  and Krishnarao v. Firm Radhakisan Ramshai and another In the Orissa High Court decision two accused were being tried for an offence under Section 500 I.P.C. It is no doubt stated in the said decision that in a trial for defamation

precedents.case_name: Krishnarao v. Firm Radhakisan Ramshai and another
precedents.cited_proposition: in a suit for damages for defamation the law requires that the plaint ought to allege the publication of the defamatory statement, set out the actual words used

precedents.citation: Emperor v. Col. Bholanath  1  51 I.L.R. 1929. All. 313

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the respondent has invited our attention to the decisions reported in Emperor v. Col. Bholanath  1 , K. S. Namjundaiah v. Setti Chikka Tippanna  2  and Dhruba Charan Khandal v. Dinabandhu Patri  3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: it is unnecessary to prove the exact words used by the accused, for the purpose of supporting a conviction for oral defamation. It is sufficient to prove the purport or substance of the defamatory imputations

precedents.citation: K. S. Namjundaiah v. Setti Chikka Tippanna  2  1952 Criminal Law Journal Mysore 1633

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Col. Bholanath  1 , K. S. Namjundaiah v. Setti Chikka Tippanna  2  and Dhruba Charan Khandal v. Dinabandhu Patri  3 . In the first decision of the Allahabad High Court, Mukherji, J. observed While I am not prepared to lay down, as a universal proposition

precedents.case_name: K. S. Namjundaiah v. Setti Chikka Tippanna
precedents.cited_proposition: it is sufficient for the purpose of Sections 499 and 500 I. C. that if witnesses are agreed in a substantial measure on the words of imputation uttered as it is hardly possible or necessary to reproduce every word or expression used

precedents.citation: Dhruba Charan Khandal v. Dinabandhu Patri  3 . A.I.R. 1966 Orissa 15.

anchor.surface_text: K. S. Namjundaiah v. Setti Chikka Tippanna  2  and Dhruba Charan Khandal v. Dinabandhu Patri  3 . In the first decision of the Allahabad High Court, Mukherji, J. observed While I am not prepared to lay down, as a universal proposition, that in no case where the actual words used have not been proved

precedents.case_name: Dhruba Charan Khandal v. Dinabandhu Patri
precedents.cited_proposition: for the purpose of an offence under Section 500 I.P.C. it is enough if the witnesses are agreed in a substantial measure on the words of imputation uttered, for it is not possible even for a most honest witness to reproduce every such word or expression

precedents.citation: Sarat Chandra Das and another v. The State  1  A. I. R. 1952 Orissa 351

anchor.surface_text: This decision has also distinguished the earlier decision in Sarat Chandra Das and another v. The State  1  on the ground that the observations contained in that judgment that the precise words uttered against the complainant should find a place in the charge were made in the context of the court dealing with two accused

precedents.case_name: Sarat Chandra Das and another v. The State
precedents.cited_proposition: the precise words uttered against the complainant should find a place in the charge

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against High Court order dismissed; High Court order upheld directing further inquiry into the defamation complaint under Section 500 IPC.

edges.explanation: Argument of no prima facie case due to lack of attribution undercuts the application of CrPC Section 203 requiring prima facie case for dismissal

anchor.surface_text: nts. The High Court, after a reference to the material evidence on record, as well as the allegations stated to have been made by the appellants, has

edges.explanation: Argument that no evidence of specific allegations addresses the issue of whether prima facie case made out under Sections 202/203
The argument supporting broader interpretation under IPC supports the holding of prima facie case existence without strict verbatim requirements.
The argument on inapplicability of strict English libel principles to IPC defamation addresses assessment of prima facie case from complaint materials under Section 202.

The argument states that under Sections 202/203 CrPC, magistrate forms opinion on prima facie case from complaint (citing Chandra Deo Singh), grounding the concept's definition of prima facie case sufficiency from allegations.
The argument on forming prima facie opinion from complaint under 202/203 (not needing conviction sufficiency) supports the holding that prima facie case is made out from complaint materials.
